The main functions treated in this chapter are the exponential integrals \mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right) , E_{1}\left(z\right) , and \mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right) ; the logarithmic integral \mathrm{li}\left(x\right) ; the sine integrals \mathrm{Si}\left(z\right) and \mathrm{si}\left(z\right) ; the cosine integrals \mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right) and \mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right).

The principal value of the exponential integral E_{1}\left(z\right) is defined by E_{1}\left(z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t}\mathrm{d}t, subject to z\neq 0, where the path does not cross the negative real axis or pass through the origin.
As in the case of the logarithm (§LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG) there is a cutalong the interval (-\infty,0] and the principal value is two-valued on (-\infty,0).
Unless indicated otherwise, it is assumed throughout the DLMF that E_{1}\left(z\right) assumes its principal value.
This is also true of the functions \mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right) and \mathrm{Chi}\left(z\right) defined in §LABEL:sec:EX.DF.SC.
E_{1}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t+z}\mathrm{d}t, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi.
\mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{1-e^{-t}}{t}\mathrm{d}t.
\mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right) is sometimes called the complementary exponential integral.
It is entire.
E_{1}\left(z\right)=\mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right)-\ln z-\gamma.
In the next three equations x>0.

\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)=-\,\pvint_{-x}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t}\mathrm{d}t= \pvint_{-\infty}^{x}\frac{e^{t}}{t}\mathrm{d}t, \mathrm{Ei}\left(-x\right)=-\int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t}\mathrm{d}t=-E_{1 }\left(x\right), \mathrm{Ei}\left(\pm x\right)=-\mathrm{Ein}\left(\mp x\right)+\ln x+\gamma.
( \mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right) is undefined when x=0 , or when x is not real.)
The logarithmic integral is defined by \mathrm{li}\left(x\right)=\pvint_{0}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\ln t}=\mathrm{Ei} \left(\ln x\right), subject to x>1.
The generalized exponential integral E_{p}\left(z\right) , p\in\mathbb{C} , is treated in Chapter LABEL:ch:IG.
\mathrm{Si}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\sin t}{t}\mathrm{d}t.
\mathrm{Si}\left(z\right) is an odd entire function.
\mathrm{si}\left(z\right)=-\int_{z}^{\infty}\frac{\sin t}{t}\mathrm{d}t= \mathrm{Si}\left(z\right)-\tfrac{1}{2}\pi.
\mathrm{Ci}(z)=-\int_{z}^{\infty}\frac{\cos t}{t}\mathrm{d}t, where the path does not cross the negative real axis or pass through theorigin.
This is the principal value; compare (LABEL:eq:EX.DF.E1).
\mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{1-\cos t}{t}\mathrm{d}t.
\mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right) is an even entire function.
\mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right)=-\mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right)+\ln z+\gamma.
\lim_{x\to\infty}\mathrm{Si}\left(x\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, \lim_{x\to\infty}\mathrm{Ci}\left(x\right)=0.

para.sentence: Analytic continuation of the principal value of E_{1}\left(z\right) yields a multi-valued function with branch points at z=0 and z=\infty.
The general value of E_{1}\left(z\right) is given by E_{1}\left(z\right)=\mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right)-\operatorname{Ln}z-\gamma; compare (LABEL:eq:EX.DF.E4) and (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.GenLog).

Thus E_{1}\left(ze^{2m\pi i}\right)=E_{1}\left(z\right)-2m\pi i, subject to m\in\mathbb{Z}, and E_{1}\left(ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\mathrm{Ein}\left(-z\right)-\ln z-\gamma\mp\pi i, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi.

The general values of the other functions are defined in a similar manner, and \mathrm{Ci}\left(ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\pm\pi i+\mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right), , \mathrm{Chi}\left(ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\pm\pi i+\mathrm{Chi}\left(z\right), , \mathrm{f}\left(ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\pi e^{\mp iz}-\mathrm{f}\left(z\right), , \mathrm{g}\left(ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)=\mp\pi ie^{\mp iz}+\mathrm{g}\left(z \right).

Unless indicated otherwise, in the rest of this chapter and elsewhere in the DLMF the functions E_{1}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{Chi}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{f}\left(z\right) , and \mathrm{g}\left(z\right) assume their principal values, that is, the branches that are real on the positive real axis and two-valued on the negative real axis.

When x>0 , E_{1}\left(-x\pm i0\right)=-\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)\mp i\pi, \mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)=-\tfrac{1}{2}(E_{1}\left(-x+i0\right)+E_{1}\left(-x- i0\right)), \tfrac{1}{2}(\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)+E_{1}\left(x\right))=\mathrm{Shi}\left( x\right)=-i\mathrm{Si}\left(ix\right), \tfrac{1}{2}(\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)-E_{1}\left(x\right))=\mathrm{Chi}\left( x\right)=\mathrm{Ci}\left(ix\right)-\tfrac{1}{2}\pi i.

When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , \mathrm{Si}\left(z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}i(E_{1}\left(-iz\right)-E_{1}\left(iz \right))+\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right)=-\tfrac{1}{2}(E_{1}\left(iz\right)+E_{1}\left(-iz \right)), \mathrm{g}\left(z\right)\pm i\mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=E_{1}\left(\mp iz\right) e^{\mp iz}.
\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right)=\gamma+\ln x+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{x^{n}}{n! \thinspace n}, subject to x>0.
E_{1}\left(z\right)=-\gamma-\ln z-\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}z^{n}}{n! \thinspace n}.
E_{1}\left(z\right)=-\ln z+e^{-z}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}\psi\left( n+1\right), where \psi denotes the logarithmic derivative of the gamma function (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def.GP).

\mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n-1}z^{n}}{n! \thinspace n}, \mathrm{Si}\left(z\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}z^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!(2 n+1)}, \mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right)=\gamma+\ln z+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}z^{2n} }{(2n)!(2n)}.
The series in this section converge for all finite values of x and |z|.

\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-at}}{t+b}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{iat} }{t+ib}\mathrm{d}t=e^{ab}E_{1}\left(ab\right), subject to a>0, b>0, e^{x}\int_{0}^{\alpha}\frac{e^{-xt}}{1-t}\mathrm{d}t=\mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right) -\mathrm{Ei}\left((1-\alpha)x\right), subject to 0\leq\alpha<1, x>0.

\int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{e^{it}}{a^{2}+t^{2}}\mathrm{d}t=\frac{i}{2a}\left(e^{a} E_{1}\left(a-ix\right)-e^{-a}E_{1}\left(-a-ix\right)\right), subject to a>0, x>0, \int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{te^{it}}{a^{2}+t^{2}}\mathrm{d}t=\tfrac{1}{2}\left(e^{a }E_{1}\left(a-ix\right)+e^{-a}E_{1}\left(-a-ix\right)\right), subject to a>0, x>0.

\int_{0}^{1}\frac{e^{-at}\sin\left(bt\right)}{t}\mathrm{d}t=\Im\mathrm{Ein} \left(a+ib\right), subject to a,b\in\mathbb{R}, \int_{0}^{1}\frac{e^{-at}(1-\cos\left(bt\right))}{t}\mathrm{d}t=\Re\mathrm{Ein }\left(a+ib\right)-\mathrm{Ein}\left(a\right), subject to a,b\in\mathbb{R}.

Many integrals with exponentials and rational functions, for example, integrals of the type \int e^{z}R(z)\mathrm{d}z , where R(z) is an arbitrary rationalfunction, can be represented in finite form in terms of the function E_{1}\left(z\right) and elementary functions; see ( , p. 42) .

When z\in\mathbb{C} \mathrm{si}\left(z\right)=-\int_{0}^{\pi/2}e^{-z\cos t}\cos\left(z\sin t\right )\mathrm{d}t, \mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right)-\mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}e^{-z \cos t}\sin\left(z\sin t\right)\mathrm{d}t, \int_{0}^{1}\frac{(1-e^{-at})\cos\left(bt\right)}{t}\mathrm{d}t=\Re\mathrm{Ein }\left(a+ib\right)-\mathrm{Cin}\left(b\right), subject to a,b\in\mathbb{R}.
\mathrm{g}\left(z\right)+i\mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=e^{-iz}\int_{z}^{\infty} \frac{e^{it}}{t}\mathrm{d}t, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi.
The path of integration does not cross the negative real axis or pass through the origin.

\mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sin t}{t+z}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{ 0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}}{t^{2}+1}\mathrm{d}t, , \mathrm{g}\left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\cos t}{t+z}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{ 0}^{\infty}\frac{te^{-zt}}{t^{2}+1}\mathrm{d}t.
The first integrals on the right-hand sides apply when |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi ; the second ones when \Re z\geq 0 and (in the case of (LABEL:eq:EX.IR.I14)) z\neq 0.

When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi \mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=2\int_{0}^{\infty}K_{0}\left(2\sqrt{zt}\right)\cos t \mathrm{d}t, , \mathrm{g}\left(z\right)=2\int_{0}^{\infty}K_{0}\left(2\sqrt{zt}\right)\sin t \mathrm{d}t.
For K_{0} see §LABEL:sec:BS.MDEF.SS.
In this section x>0.

\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(1+\frac{2}{x}\right)<e^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right)<\ln\left(1+ \frac{1}{x}\right), \frac{x}{x+1}<xe^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right)<\frac{x+1}{x+2}, \frac{x(x+3)}{x^{2}+4x+2}<xe^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right)<\frac{x^{2}+5x+2}{x^{2}+6x +6}.

See also ( , pp. 287–290) .

E_{1}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}\left(\frac{c_{0}}{z}+\frac{c_{1}}{z(z+1)}+\frac{2!c _{2}}{z(z+1)(z+2)}+\frac{3!c_{3}}{z(z+1)(z+2)(z+3)}+\cdots\right), subject to \Re z>0, where c_{0}=1, c_{1}=-1, c_{2}=\tfrac{1}{2}, c_{3}=-\tfrac{1}{3}, c_{4}=\tfrac{1}{6}, and c_{k}=-\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}\frac{c_{j}}{k-j}, subject to k\geq 1.

When |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi the remainder is bounded in magnitude by the first neglected term, and has the same sign when \operatorname{ph}z=0.

The remainder terms are given by \mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=\frac{1}{z}\sum_{m=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{m}\frac{(2m)!}{z^{2m }}+R_{n}^{(\mathrm{f})}(z), , \mathrm{g}\left(z\right)=\frac{1}{z^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{m}\frac{(2m+1)!} {z^{2m}}+R_{n}^{(\mathrm{g})}(z), where, for n=0,1,2,\dots , R_{n}^{(\mathrm{f})}(z)=(-1)^{n}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}t^{2n}}{t^{2}+1} \mathrm{d}t, , R_{n}^{(\mathrm{g})}(z)=(-1)^{n}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}t^{2n+1}}{t^{2}+ 1}\mathrm{d}t.

subsection.title: The Gibbs Phenomenon

para.sentence: Consider the Fourier series \sin x+\tfrac{1}{3}\sin\left(3x\right)+\tfrac{1}{5}\sin\left(5x\right)+\dots= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{4}\pi,&0<x<\pi,\\ 0,&x=0,\\ -\frac{1}{4}\pi,&-\pi<x<0.\end{cases } The n th partial sum is given by S_{n}(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\frac{\sin\left((2k+1)x\right)}{2k+1}=\frac{1}{2}\int _{0}^{x}\frac{\sin\left(2nt\right)}{\sin t}\mathrm{d}t=\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Si} \left(2nx\right)+R_{n}(x), where R_{n}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{x}\left(\frac{1}{\sin t}-\frac{1}{t}\right)\sin \left(2nt\right)\mathrm{d}t.
By integration by parts R_{n}(x)=O\left(n^{-1}\right), subject to n\to\infty, uniformly for x\in[-\pi,\pi].
Hence, if x is fixed and n\to\infty , then S_{n}(x)\to\frac{1}{4}\pi , 0 , or -\frac{1}{4}\pi according as 0<x<\pi , x=0 , or -\pi<x<0 ; compare (LABEL:eq:EX.DF.S6).
These limits are not approached uniformly, however.
The first maximum of \frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Si}\left(x\right) for positive x occurs at x=\pi and equals (1.1789\dots)\times\frac{1}{4}\p i; compare Figure LABEL:fig:EX.GR.E2.

Hence if x=\pi/(2n) and n\to\infty , then the limiting value of S_{n}(x) overshoots \frac{1}{4}\pi by approximately 18 x=\pi/n , then the limiting value of S_{n}(x) undershoots \frac{1}{4}\pi byapproximately 10LABEL:fig:EX.GR.E3.
This nonuniformity of convergence is an illustration of the Gibbs phenomenon.
It occurs with Fourier-series expansions of all piecewise continuous functions.
See ( ) for additional graphs and information.

subsection.title: Number-Theoretic Significance of \mathrm{li}\left(x\right)

para.sentence: ( ) cites work with applications from diffusion theory, transport problems, the study of the radiative equilibrium of stellar atmospheres, and the evaluation of exchange integrals occurring in quantum mechanics.
For applications in astrophysics, see also ( ) .
( ) gives an application to electromagnetic theory (radiation of a linear half-wave oscillator), in which sine and cosine integrals are used.

For small or moderate values of x and |z| , the expansion in power series (§LABEL:sec:EX.MS) or in series of spherical Bessel functions (§LABEL:sec:EX.FS.SBF) can be used. For large x or |z| these series suffer from slow convergence or cancellation (or both).

However, this problem is less severe for the series of spherical Bessel functions because of their more rapid rate of convergence, and also (except in the case of (LABEL:eq:EX.FS.SBF3)) absence of cancellation when z=x ( >0 ).
For large x and \left|z\right| , expansions in inverse factorial series (§LABEL:sec:EX.FS.IFS) or asymptotic expansions (§LABEL:sec:EX.AE) are available.
The attainable accuracy of the asymptotic expansions can be increased considerably by exponential improvement.
Also, other ranges of \operatorname{ph}z can be covered by use of the continuation formulas of §LABEL:sec:EX.AC.
Quadrature of the integral representations is another effective method.
For example, the Gauss-Laguerre formula (§LABEL:sec:NM.QUA.GAUSS) can be applied to (LABEL:eq:EX.DF.E2); see ( ) and ( ) .
For an application of the Gauss-Legendre formula (§LABEL:sec:NM.QUA.GAUSS) see ( ) .
Lastly, the continued fraction (LABEL:eq:EX.CF.CF) can be used if |z| is bounded away from the origin.
Convergence becomes slow when z is near the negative real axis, however.
Power series, asymptotic expansions, and quadrature can also be used to compute the functions \mathrm{f}\left(z\right) and \mathrm{g}\left(z\right).
In addition, ( ) developed a recurrence procedure, as follows.

For n=0,1,2,\dots , define A_{n}=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{te^{-zt}}{1+t^{2}}\left(\frac{t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \right)^{n}\mathrm{d}t, B_{n}=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}}{1+t^{2}}\left(\frac{t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \right)^{n}\mathrm{d}t, C_{n}=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}\left(\frac{t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{n}\mathrm{d}t.
Then \mathrm{f}\left(z\right)=B_{0} , \mathrm{g}\left(z\right)=A_{0} , and A_{n-1}=A_{n}+\frac{z}{2n}C_{n}, B_{n-1}=\frac{2nB_{n}+zA_{n-1}}{2n-1}, C_{n-1}=C_{n}+B_{n-1} subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.

A_{0} , B_{0} , and C_{0} can be computed by Miller’s algorithm (§LABEL:sec:NM.LDE.MA), starting with initial values (A_{N},B_{N},C_{N})=(1,0,0) , say, where N is an arbitrary large integer, and normalizing via C_{0}=1/z.

Zeros of \mathrm{Ci}\left(x\right) and \mathrm{si}\left(x\right) can be computed to high precision by Newton’s rule (§LABEL:sec:NM.NLE.NEWTON), using values supplied by the asymptotic expansion (LABEL:eq:EX.SC.Z1) as initial approximations.
For a comprehensive survey of computational methods for the functions treated in this chapter, see ( , Ch. IV) .

para.sentence: ( ) gives several minimax polynomial and rational approximations for E_{1}\left(x\right)+\ln x , xe^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right) , and the auxiliary functions \mathrm{f}\left(x\right) and \mathrm{g}\left(x\right).
These are included in ( , Ch. 5) .

( ) provides rational approximations for the sine and cosine integrals and for the auxiliary functions \mathrm{f} and \mathrm{g} , with accuracies up to 20S.
( ) gives Chebyshev coefficients for -E_{1}\left(x\right)-\ln|x| for -4\leq x\leq 4 and e^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right) for x\geq 4 (20D).
( ) covers \mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right) for x\leq-4 (20D), and \mathrm{Si}\left(x\right) and \mathrm{Ci}\left(x\right) for x\geq 4 (20D).
( , pp. 41–42) gives Chebyshev expansions of \mathrm{Ein}\left(ax\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(ax\right) , and \mathrm{Cin}\left(ax\right) for -1\leq x\leq 1 , a\in\mathbb{C}.
The coefficients are given in terms of series of Bessel functions.

( , pp. 321–322) covers \mathrm{Ein}\left(x\right) and -\mathrm{Ein}\left(-x\right) for 0\leq x\leq 8 (the Chebyshev coefficients are given to 20D); E_{1}\left(x\right) for x\geq 5 (20D), and \mathrm{Ei}\left(x\right) for x\geq 8 (15D).
Coefficients for the sine and cosine integrals are given on pp. 325–327.

( , p. 25) gives a Chebyshev expansion near infinity for the confluent hypergeometric U -function (§LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU) from which Chebyshev expansions near infinity for E_{1}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{f}\left(z\right) ,and \mathrm{g}\left(z\right) follow by using (LABEL:eq:EX.OF.O2) and (LABEL:eq:EX.OF.O3).
Luke also includes a recursion scheme for computing the coefficients in the expansions of the U functions.
If |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi the scheme can be used in backward direction.

( , pp. 402, 410, and 415–421) gives main diagonal Padé approximations for \mathrm{Ein}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(z\right) , \mathrm{Cin}\left(z\right) (valid near the origin), and E_{1}\left(z\right) (valid for large |z| ); approximate errors are given for a selection of z -values.
